notes.title: 79 files built without browser testing is a risk
notes.content: The entire UI was written in one pass without seeing a single pixel. This could mean everything works fine, or it could mean 30 minutes of fixing import paths and Tailwind config. The first action in the next session MUST be booting the UI.

notes.title: Data files are the source of truth, not the database
notes.content: We chose JSON + Markdown files over SQLite or any database. Reason: git-friendly, AI can read/write directly, human-readable. Optional SQLite cache for complex queries later. This is a core architectural decision — don't revisit unless file I/O becomes a bottleneck.

notes.title: Open source the tool, sell the intelligence layer
notes.content: File format + cursor rule + basic UI should be free/open-source. Chargeable value is in: automated diagnostics, AI agents, cross-project dashboards, cloud hosting. But validate with real usage first before any product decisions.

notes.title: User prefers 'go big or fuck off' over MVP
notes.content: The user consistently pushes for ambitious scope and beautiful UI. They prefer building something impressive over something minimal. When suggesting approaches, lean toward the ambitious option. BUT — also be the voice of 'let's test what we have' when we're building in the dark.

notes.title: User is non-technical but highly capable
notes.content: The user describes themselves as 'not a developer' but has built a 139K-line production app with AI assistance. They think in product terms, not engineering terms. Explain things in outcomes and user experience, not in technical implementation details. They also ship insanely fast — 17 features in one session on Pillar.

notes.title: Tool needs a real name before open-source launch
notes.content: Current name 'dev-track' is a placeholder. Discussed options: Forge (crowded), Keystone, Pylon, Tack, Axis. User didn't pick one. Revisit when ready to ship publicly. Not blocking for development.

notes.title: AI didn't follow dev-track rules until explicitly asked
notes.content: In the first boot session, the AI (me) did not proactively manage issues, changelog, or brain notes despite having full autonomy permissions in the cursor rule. Root cause: the rule had trigger-based activation ('let's go') but no cold-start instruction. Fixed by adding a mandatory cold-start section that runs on every first message. VALIDATE: open a new chat window and confirm the AI orients itself automatically.

notes.title: All 11 views rendered on first browser test — architecture is solid
notes.content: 79 files written blind and they all work. The Hono + React + Tailwind + TypeScript stack is clean. Only 3 config issues (Tailwind paths, PostCSS config, CSS import order) — all environmental, not logic bugs. This validates the approach of building breadth-first and testing later for this type of structured/generated code.
